questions.question_text: How many tangents can a circle have?
hints: Consider different positions of a point relative to the circle (inside, on, outside).
Recall the three cases discussed in Section 10.3.

questions.question_text: Fill in the blanks : (i) A tangent to a circle intersects it in ______ point (s). (ii) A line intersecting a circle in two points is called a ______. (iii) A circle can have ______ parallel tangents at the most. (iv) The common point of a tangent to a circle and the circle is called ______.
hints: Refer to definitions of tangent, secant, and point of contact.
Think about the maximum number of tangents parallel to a given secant.

questions.question_text: A tangent PQ at a point P of a circle of radius 5 cm meets a line through the centre O at a point Q so that OQ = 12 cm. Length PQ is : (A) 12 cm (B) 13 cm (C) 8.5 cm (D) √119 cm.
hints: Apply Theorem 10.1: tangent is perpendicular to radius at point of contact.
Use Pythagoras theorem in right triangle OPQ.

questions.question_text: Draw a circle and two lines parallel to a given line such that one is a tangent and the other, a secant to the circle.
hints: Recall Activity 2: lines parallel to a secant can become tangents.
Consider the positions where the chord length becomes zero.

questions.question_text: From a point Q, the length of the tangent to a circle is 24 cm and the distance of Q from the centre is 25 cm. The radius of the circle is (A) 7 cm (B) 12 cm (C) 15 cm (D) 24.5 cm
hints: Use Theorem 10.2: tangents from external point are equal.
Apply Pythagoras theorem: radius² = (distance from centre)² - (tangent length)².

questions.question_text: In Fig. 10.11, if TP and TQ are the two tangents to a circle with centre O so that ∠ POQ = 110°, then ∠ PTQ is equal to (A) 60° (B) 70° (C) 80° (D) 90°
hints: Use Theorem 10.2: tangents from external point are equal, so triangle PTQ is isosceles.
Sum of angles in quadrilateral OPTQ is 360°. Use right angles at P and Q.

questions.question_text: If tangents PA and PB from a point P to a circle with centre O are inclined to each other at angle of 80°, then ∠ POA is equal to (A) 50° (B) 60° (C) 70° (D) 80°
hints: Tangents from external point are equal, so triangle PAB is isosceles.
OP bisects angle APB (Theorem 10.2 remark). Use right triangle OPA.

questions.question_text: Prove that the tangents drawn at the ends of a diameter of a circle are parallel.
hints: Use Theorem 10.1: tangent is perpendicular to radius at point of contact.
If two lines are perpendicular to the same line, they are parallel.

questions.question_text: Prove that the perpendicular at the point of contact to the tangent to a circle passes through the centre.
hints: This is essentially the converse of Theorem 10.1.
Assume a line through point of contact perpendicular to tangent. Show it must contain centre.

questions.question_text: The length of a tangent from a point A at distance 5 cm from the centre of the circle is 4 cm. Find the radius of the circle.
hints: Apply Pythagoras theorem: radius² = (distance from centre)² - (tangent length)².
Similar to Q1 but with numbers given differently.

questions.question_text: Two concentric circles are of radii 5 cm and 3 cm. Find the length of the chord of the larger circle which touches the smaller circle.
hints: Refer to Example 1: chord of larger circle touching smaller circle is bisected at point of contact.
Use Pythagoras theorem in right triangle formed by radius of smaller circle, half chord, and radius of larger circle.

questions.question_text: A quadrilateral ABCD is drawn to circumscribe a circle (see Fig. 10.12). Prove that AB + CD = AD + BC
hints: Use Theorem 10.2: lengths of tangents from an external point to a circle are equal.
Let points of contact be P, Q, R, S on sides AB, BC, CD, DA respectively. Express sides in terms of tangent segments.

questions.question_text: In Fig. 10.13, XY and X′Y′ are two parallel tangents to a circle with centre O and another tangent AB with point of contact C intersecting XY at A and X′Y′ at B. Prove that ∠ AOB = 90°.
hints: Join OA, OB, OC. Use Theorem 10.1: tangents are perpendicular to radius at point of contact.
Consider triangles OAC and OBC. Use angle sum property in quadrilateral AOB?

questions.question_text: Prove that the angle between the two tangents drawn from an external point to a circle is supplementary to the angle subtended by the line-segment joining the points of contact at the centre.
hints: Let external point P, tangents PA and PB, centre O. Need to prove ∠APB + ∠AOB = 180°.
Use Theorem 10.2: PA = PB, so triangle PAB is isosceles. Also OA ⟂ PA, OB ⟂ PB.

questions.question_text: Prove that the parallelogram circumscribing a circle is a rhombus.
hints: Use result of Q8: for circumscribed quadrilateral, sum of opposite sides are equal.
In parallelogram, opposite sides are equal. Combine to show all sides equal.

questions.question_text: A triangle ABC is drawn to circumscribe a circle of radius 4 cm such that the segments BD and DC into which BC is divided by the point of contact D are of lengths 8 cm and 6 cm respectively (see Fig. 10.14). Find the sides AB and AC.
hints: Let points of contact on AB, AC be E and F respectively. Use Theorem 10.2: tangents from a point to circle are equal.
Set AE = AF = x. Then AB = x + 8, AC = x + 6, BC = 14. Use Heron's formula or other methods to find x.

questions.question_text: Prove that opposite sides of a quadrilateral circumscribing a circle subtend supplementary angles at the centre of the circle.
hints: Let quadrilateral ABCD circumscribe circle with centre O. Need to prove ∠AOB + ∠COD = 180° and ∠BOC + ∠DOA = 180°.
Join OA, OB, OC, OD to points of contact. Use fact that tangents are perpendicular to radii and angle sum around point O is 360°.
